appBar.qualityCorp: Water quality lab analytics values (BD Corporativa)

timeRange.initYear: Since the beginning of the year
timeRange.initHydroYear: Since the beginning of the hydrological year

environmentalFlow.noDataError: No data available from last day

CPPiezometerFilterForm.initYear: Since the beginning of this year
CPPiezometerFilterForm.initHydroYear: Since the beginning of the hydrological plan (15/21)

aemet.lastActualizationInfo: Last date time of the observation period, these are data from the period of the hour prior to the one indicated by this field (UTC time)
aemet.altitudeinfo: Altitude of the station in meters above sea level
aemet.lastHourRainfallInfo: Accumulated rainfall, measured by the pluviometer, during the 60 minutes prior to the time indicated by the observation period
aemet.windSpeedInfo: Mean wind speed, scalar mean of samples acquired every 0.25 or 1 second in the 10-minute period prior to that indicated
aemet.windDirectionInfo: Average wind direction, in the period of 10 minutes prior to the indicated date
aemet.soilTemperatureInfo: Temperature next to the ground, in the period of 10 minutes prior to the indicated date
aemet.airTemperatureInfo: Temperature of the air corresponding to the indicated date
aemet.relativeHumidityInfo: Relative humidity of the air corresponding to the indicated date
aemet.setRange: Set a range of at least 5 days
aemet.noData: No data available, change the search criteria

help.environmentalFlow:
[NOTE: The data for this visualisation come from the SAIH and are updated in real time, every 5 minutes]

This visualisation allows you to see at a first glance the ecological flow status of the measuring stations and river sections.
The circular icons represent measuring stations:

  • Red colour at the measuring station indicates that the last daily average flow data of that measuring station is below the ecological flow limit corresponding to the respective period of the year.
  • The blue colour of the measuring station indicates that the last daily average flow data of that measuring station is above the ecological flow limit for the respective period of the year.

By clicking on the measuring station, the temporal evolution of the flow at the measuring station for the selected time interval can be seen in a graph:

  • In this graph, the level of the ecological flow at each station of the year is shown with a dotted grey line;
  • Also, a green dashed line representing the generating flow is shown (only if it exists, because there is not a defined generating flow in all cases).

It will also be possible to make an estimated prediction of the flow status with an uncertainty interval, with the following range and time resolution options:

  • 15-day prediction, with daily step.
  • 7-month forecast, with monthly / daily step.
  • 12-month forecast, with monthly / daily step.

The river sections are also coloured, following the same logic as in the case of the measuring stations.

By placing the mouse pointer over a river section, summary information of interest is displayed.
help.dams:
[NOTE: The data for this display come from the SAIH and are updated in real time, every 5 minutes]

This visualisation allows you to see at a first glance the status of the reservoirs.
Specifically, the reservoir colours represent the status of the reservoir volume based on the following colouring criteria:

  • Red colour in the reservoir indicates that the latest daily average volume data for that reservoir is above the upper limit corresponding to the respective period of the year.
  • Orange colour in the reservoir indicates that the latest daily average volume data for that reservoir is below the lower limit for the respective period of the year.
  • Blue colour on the reservoir indicates that the latest daily average volume data for that reservoir is between the lower and upper limit for the respective period of the year.

By clicking on the reservoir, the time evolution of the following variables in the reservoir for the selected time interval can be seen in a graph:

  • Level
  • Volume
  • Outflow
  • Inflow
  • Surface area

In the volume graph, the minimum and maximum volumes defined for the reservoir and for the current period of the year are shown with dotted lines.

Likewise, for the variables indicated above, it will be possible to make an estimated prediction of their value with their uncertainty interval, with the following options of scope and temporal resolution:

  • 15-day forecast, with daily step.
  • 7-month forecast, with a monthly / daily step.
  • 12-month forecast, with monthly/daily step.

By hovering the mouse pointer over an ambalse, its name is displayed.
help.piezometry:
NOTE: The data for this visualisation come from the Corporate Database and are updated in real time; the source can be accessed directly]

This visualisation allows you to consult the piezometric status of the Segura Hydrographic Demarcation. More specifically, using the top right menu, the following information can be accessed:

  • "Latest data" menu option: Depth of groundwater in the network probing and aquifers; PNP, in metres (m). At the bottom right, a legend is displayed with the meaning of each colour and the corresponding depth intervals.
  • Last year" menu option: Variation of the depth of groundwater (piezometers and aquifers) in the last year, in metres (m). At the bottom right, a legend is displayed with the meaning of each colour and the corresponding depth variation intervals.
  • Menu option "Since the beginning of this year": Variation of the depth of groundwater (piezometers and aquifers) since the beginning of the current year, in metres (m). At the bottom right, a legend is displayed with the meaning of each colour and the corresponding depth variation intervals.
  • Menu option "Since the beginning of the hydrological plan (15/21)": Variation of the depth of groundwater (piezometers and aquifers) since the start of the current hydrological plan (in this case 15/21), in metres (m). At the bottom right, a legend is displayed with the meaning of each colour and the corresponding depth variation intervals.
  • "First saved data" menu option: Variation of the depth of groundwater (piezometers and aquifers) since the start of the control, in metres (m). At the bottom right, a legend is displayed with the meaning of each colour and the corresponding depth variation intervals.

When changing from one menu item to another, it is necessary to click on the "UPDATE" button.

The menu offers the option to show/hide piezometers and/or aquifers by clicking on the corresponding option and then on the "UPDATE" button.

By hovering the mouse pointer over a piezometer or an aquifer, a data summary is displayed; in the case of aquifers, the data represent the average value of the piezometers in the aquifer.

By clicking on a piezometer, a pop-up window is displayed in which the time evolution of the depth (PNP) provided by that piezometer can be shown for the selected time interval. It will also be possible to make an estimated future prediction of the PNP.
help.marmenor:
[NOTE: The data for this display come from the SAIH and are updated in real time, every 5 minutes]

This visualisation allows you to consult the piezometric status of the Mar Menor. More specifically, by clicking with the mouse on each of the piezometric points of the Mar Menor, access is granted to the following information:

  • Level.
  • Water temperature.
  • Conductivity.
  • Salinity.
  • Total dissolved solids.
  • SIM card coverage. Showing its temporal evolution for the selected time interval.

Likewise, for the variables indicated above, it will be possible to make an estimated prediction of their value with their uncertainty interval, with the following range and time resolution options:

  • 15-day prediction, with daily step.
  • 7-month forecast, with monthly / daily step.
  • 12-month forecast, with monthly / daily step.

When hovering the mouse pointer over a piezometer, its name is displayed.
help.documentation: Click on the link provided to access the technical help document.
help.qualitySaica:
[NOTE: The data for this display come from the SAIH and are updated in real time, every 5 minutes]

This visualisation allows you to consult the status of the quality variables of the existing SAICA stations, integrated in the SAIH. More specifically, by clicking with the mouse on each of the quality stations, access is granted to the following information:

  • Water Temperature.
  • pH.
  • Conductivity
  • Dissolved Oxygen.
  • High Range Turbidimeter.
  • Ammonium.
  • Nitrates.
  • Phosphates.
  • SAC (Spectral Absorption Coefficient).

Showing its temporal evolution for the selected time interval.

Likewise, for the variables indicated above, it will be possible to make an estimated prediction of their value with their uncertainty interval, with the following range and temporal resolution options:

  • 15-day prediction, with daily step.
  • 7-month forecast, with monthly / daily step.
  • 12-month forecast, with monthly / daily step.

Hovering the mouse pointer over a piezometer displays its name and a summary of the data: the last value of each of the variables monitored at the quality station.
help.qualityCorp:
[NOTE: The data for this visualisation come from the Corporate Database and are updated in real time; the source is accessed directly]

This visualisation allows you to consult the status of surface water and groundwater quality variables managed from the Corporate Database. More specifically, by clicking with the mouse on each of the surface or groundwater bodies, access is granted to any of the physicochemical or biological quality variables that have been analysed in the laboratory and recorded in the Corporate Database. An example list of some of these quality variables is shown below:

Example of surface water quality variables:

  • % Cyanobacteria
  • 1,2-DIBROMOETHANE
  • 1,2-DIBROMO-3-CHLOROPROPANE
  • 1,2-DICHLOROPROPANE
  • 1,2,2,5,6,9,10-HBCD
  • 2,3,4,6-TETRACHLOROPHENOL
  • 2,4,5-TRICHLOROPHENOXYACETIC ACID

Example of groundwater quality variables:

  • 1,2,3-trimethylbenzene
  • 2,2'-dithiobis-benzothiazole
  • 2(3H)-benzothiazolone
  • 1,2-DIBROMO-3-CHLOROPROPANE
  • TRANS-1,2-DICHLOROETHENE
  • CIS-1,3-DICHLOROPROPENE
  • 2-methylbenzothiazole

Showing its time evolution for the selected time interval. It will also be possible to make an estimated future prediction of the selected quality variable.
help.meteo:
[NOTE: The data for this visualisation come from AEMET's OpenData service (https://opendata.aemet.es/centrodedescargas/inicio), and therefore, they are updated in real time, i.e., based on the data publication frequency established by AEMET]

In this way, this functionality allows access to any weather data from any public AEMET weather station, which can be searched/selected by code or by name.
help.droughtIndices:
[NOTE: The data for this visualisation come from the Corporate Database and are updated in real time; the source is accessed directly]

This functionality allows access to the information on Drought Indices calculated monthly by the CHS, based on the documents “Informe de Aportaciones Acumuladas” and “Informe Mensual de Sequía”.

In this way, by means of this functionality it is possible to visualise the information indicated below: Group of visualisations I

  • Shortage index of UTE I Principal (Subsistema Cuenca).
  • Shortage Index UTE I Principal (Subsistema Trasvase).
  • Global Scarcity Index. Where labels and coloured horizontal bars indicate a Normal, Pre-alert, Alert or Emergency status.

Group of visualisations II A second group of visualisations shows information on Shortfall and Prolonged Drought for the various systems in the basin, in table format.

Group of visualisations III In a third group of visualisations, the information on Shortfall and Prolonged Drought of the different systems of the basin is shown again, this time in map format. Colour labels indicating the representative intervals of the Shortfall Indices and Prolonged Drought Indices are included.
help.l1:
[NOTE: The data for this visualisation come on the one hand from the SAIH and are updated in real time, every 5 minutes. On the other hand, they come from various publicly available meteorological services (see detailed explanation below)]

On the other hand, they come from various publicly available meteorological services (see detailed explanation below)].

Data and methods used Regarding seasonal forecasts and reference observations, seasonal forecasts from three forecast systems available in the C3S Climate Data Store (CDS) at the time of the QA4Seas project are analysed: ECMWF SEAS5 (Johnson et al. 2019), Météo France System 5 (Batté et al. 2018), and Met Office GloSea5 (MacLachlan et al. 2015). Hindcasts for monthly mean amounts are available on a common global grid of 1∘.

The common period for which hindcasts are available from the three forecasting systems is 1993-2020. Although additional hindcasts are available for the individual models, the common hindcast period is used for the calibration and verification of all forecast systems. It should be noted that this homogenisation of the data comes at the cost of potentially misinterpreting the skill of the (recalibrated) forecasts due to the short training and verification periods. Data from the ECMWF ERA-Interim analysis and the Segura SAHI rain gauge network are used as a reference for both training and verification.

The final step of the prediction system is a "multi-model combination" system, which through machine-learning techniques described in the technical documentation delivered, is capable of making reliable predictions of the variables requested by the different lines of the project.

Functionality With this functionality, a 15-day and 7-month weather forecast can be made with a step of 1 day. The forecasts are displayed on an interactive map on which a specific predicted day can be accessed.

Also, by clicking on the map, a summary of the following data is displayed:

  • Temperature at 2 metres.
  • Wind speed components at 10 metres.
  • Pressure.
  • Evaporation.
  • Humidity.
  • Accumulated precipitation (rain, snow, ice).
  • Radiation.
help.l2:
[NOTE: The data for this visualisation come from the SAIH and are updated in real time, 5 minutes a day, and from the L1 weather forecast, which is updated daily]

This functionality provides access to the results of daily 15-day and 7-month hydrological and water quality simulations. The simulated model is a model and generates a huge amount of data, which are transferred to the Hydrotwin Data Lake:

On the one hand, it generates images, such as, volumetric content of water medium in the root zones; total recharge of surface water bodies (precipitation rate); or water exchange (water recharge) between surface water bodies and groundwater bodies; water infiltration to groundwater.

In addition, data are generated for all the points and subsystems of the CHS, from inflows, reservoirs, aquifers, rivers, etc. Part of these data are used by lines L4 and L5 for planning and optimisation tasks, respectively, the rest of the data can be used for other tasks that the CHS considers of interest. Thus, other data of interest produced by the distributed hydrological model that are of interest to the user may be displayed.
help.l3:
[NOTE: The data for this visualisation come on the one hand from the weather forecast of the L1 line. On the other hand, satellite data is used, predominantly from Sentinel-2 and Sentinel-3 satellites. For crop-type mapping and tree-height estimation (an input to ET mapping) additional ancillary data are used, either from space sensors (Sentinel-1, ALOS PALSAR and GEDI) or higher level products (phenology and DEM from Copernicus Land Monitoring Service). Sentinel-2 and Sentinel-3 are accessed daily]

With this functionality, a 15-day and a 7-month agronomic forecast with a step of 1 day can be made. The predictions are displayed on an interactive map where a specific predicted day can be accessed, and the following products can be displayed:

  • 15-day forecast, with daily step, of evapotranspiration.
  • 15-day forecast, with daily step, of the water demand of the UDAs.
  • 7-month forecast, with monthly step, of the evapotranspiration.
  • 7-month forecast, with a monthly step, of the water demand of the UDAs.
  • Irrigation proposal for the next 5 days.

The predictions are displayed on an interactive map where you can access a specific predicted day / month. Also, by clicking on the different UDAs, a summary of the corresponding statistical data is displayed.

Also, the following information is displayed:

  • Crop classification history.
  • History of irrigated water.
  • History of biomass production.
help.l4:
[NOTE: The data for this visualisation come on the one hand from the simulations of line L2 and the predictions of line L3. On the other hand, the information on demand, rights and operating rules defined in the hydrological plan in force, in this case, 15/21, is used].

The present functionality allows the user to plan for 15 days and 7 months the distribution of supplies to demands, where the state of the supplies is provided from the simulations of L2 and the demands of the UDAs are provided from the predictions of L3.

The present functionality allows optimising the deficit function of the demands.

To do so, the functionality allows to play with planning criteria that can be set by the user...
help.l5:
[NOTE: The data for this visualisation come on the one hand from the simulations of line L2 and the predictions of line L3. On the other hand, the information on demand, rights and operating rules defined in the hydrological plan in force, in this case, 15/21, is used].

The present functionality allows the user to optimise at 15 days and 7 months the distribution of supplies to demands, where the state of the supplies is provided from the simulations of L2 and the demands of the DSUs are provided from the predictions of L3.

The present functionality allows the optimisation of an objective function that takes into account the deficit of the different demand units, their CO2 emissions and their hydroeconomic impact, depending on the water supplied.

To do so, the functionality allows to play with some optimisation criteria that can be set by the user...
help.waterMeter:
[NOTE: The data for this visualisation come from the Corporate Database and are updated in real time; the source is accessed directly]

The present functionality allows access to the information of all the water consumption meters controlled by the CHS from the Corporate Database, more specifically, from DBSICA.

The meters located on the map of aquifers and groundwater bodies of the CHS are shown. Clicking on any meter displays a floating window in which the evolution of the meter reading can be shown.

  • Registration of the use.
  • File number.
  • Owner of the use.
  • Concession of the use.
  • SICA code.
  • Name of the point.
  • Municipality.
  • Name of the watercourse.
  • State of the meter.
  • ID of the metering element.
help.hydroScheme:
[NOTE: The data for this visualisation come on the one hand from the simulations of line L2 and the predictions of line L3. On the other hand, the information on demand, rights and operation rules defined in the hydrological plan in force, in this case, 15/21, is used].

The present functionality shows the user the hydrological scheme of the hydrological model (developed with the Pywr library, https://github.com/pywr/pywr), used in both "L4 - Planning" and "L5 - Optimisation".

Additionally, it shows the following data:

  • Available water resources of each type of water for the next 12 months; i.e., available quantity of SURFACE, GROUND, TRASVASE, REUSED and DESALINATED water, respectively, for the next 12 months. This calculation is done live, each time this component is loaded.
  • Demands for each type of water for the next 12 months, i.e. demand for UDAs,UDUs, UDIs, UDRGs and WETLANDS, respectively, for the next 12 months. This calculation is done live, each time this component is loaded.

The total sums should be close to the figures provided by the experts of the CHS.
help.co2:
[NOTE: The data for this visualisation comes from "L4 - Planning" and/or "L5 - Optimisation"].

This functionality shows the CO2 impact of each demand unit as a result of the planning (L4) or optimisation (L5) carried out
help.hydroEconomic:
[NOTE: The data for this visualisation comes from "L4 - Planning" and/or "L5 - Optimisation"].

This functionality shows the hydro-economic impact of each demand unit as a result of the planning (L4) or optimisation (L5) carried out
